Key Match Events: England won the shootout victory over Switzerland in the Euro 2024 quarter-final
Jordan Pickford saved his fourth penalty in three major tournament shootouts
Pickford delayed Akanji's kick by walking away from the goal to pick up his water bottle
England's players took an average of 5.2 seconds from the whistle to start their run
Trent Alexander-Arnold scored the final goal to seal the win for England
Pre-Game Insights: England had a rehearsed, polished routine for penalty shootouts
Southgate gathered only the players who were on the pitch at the end of extra time before the shootout
England adopted a 'buddy system' where one player would support another after taking a penalty
Post-Match Reflections: Gareth Southgate praised England's process and said they had refined it over the years
Jordan Pickford said the save at the start of the shootout gave him confidence
Trent Alexander-Arnold said he enjoyed taking penalties and knew the spot
Bukayo Saka said he thrived on the pressure and believed in himself
Miscellaneous Highlights: England's penalty-takers had a high conversion rate, with Palmer (100%), Bellingham (100%), and Alexander-Arnold (100%) all having 100% penalty conversion rates
The average conversion rate usually hovers around the 75% mark
England are very protective of their process and don't want to give any of their upcoming opponents any hints
Others: Geir Jordet, author of the book Pressure: Lessons from the Psychology of the Penalty Shootout, praised England's approach to penalty shootouts
England's goalkeeper Pickford had detailed notes on his water bottle, telling him how to approach each Swiss taker and which way to dive
